items.title: Non-invasive action potential recordings using printed electrolyte-gated polymer field-effect transistors
authors: Adrica Kyndiah
Giulia Zoe Zemignani
Carlotta Ronchi
Gabriele Tullii
Aleksandr Khudiakov
Giuseppina Iachetta
Stefano Chiodini
Rosalia Moreddu
Fabrizio Antonio Viola
Peter J. Schwartz
Gabriel Gomila
Francesco De Angelis
Luca Sala
Maria Rosa Antognazza
Mario Caironi
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 31 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63484-1 Scalable platforms for non-invasive action potential recording are needed. Here, the authors present a reliable method to capture APs with patch-clamp-like fidelity from stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes using an Electrolyte-Gated Polymer Field-Effect Transistors.

items.title: Van der Waals β-Ga<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> thin films on polycrystalline diamond substrates
authors: Jing Ning
Zhichun Yang
Haidi Wu
Xinmeng Dong
Yaning Zhang
Yufei Chen
Xinbo Zhang
Dong Wang
Yue Hao
Jincheng Zhang
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 31 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63666-x Growth of uniform crystalline β-Ga2O3 on poly-diamond substrates is achieved using a graphene interlayer to facilitate nucleation, enabling ultralow interfacial thermal resistance, overcoming lattice mismatch and alleviating thermal expansion stress.

items.title: Machine learning climbs the Jacob’s Ladder of optoelectronic properties
authors: Malte Grunert
Max Großmann
Erich Runge
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 31 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63355-9 Graph Neural Networks achieve accurate predictions of optical spectra after finetuning on only a few hundreds of spectra from a higher rung on Jacob’s ladder of optoelectronic properties, offering an efficient route towards experimental accuracy.

items.title: Lanthanum-assisted lattice anchoring of iridium in Co<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> for efficient oxygen evolution reaction in low-iridium water electrolysis
authors: Zhuoming Wei
Yunxuan Ding
Weili Shi
Feiyang Zhang
Yuxiang Song
Xin Cui
Yu Guo
Licheng Sun
Qike Jiang
Biaobiao Zhang
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 31 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63577-x Hydrogen production via proton exchange membrane water electrolysis is limited by the high cost and scarcity of iridium catalysts. By doping lanthanum into cobalt oxide, the authors anchor iridium atoms within the oxide lattice, boosting oxygen evolution activity and stability and reducing iridium loading.

items.title: Cultivating an equity-oriented data sharing culture for African health research initiatives
authors: Nchangwi Syntia Munung
Cornelius Ewuoso
Emile R. Chimusa
Temidayo Ogundiran
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63289-2 We propose a roadmap for promoting a data-sharing culture in African health research governed by data justice and solidarity. This framework integrates dynamic consent, equitable benefit-sharing, reciprocity, data custodianship, controlled access infrastructures, and data sovereignty

items.title: Single-component-based multicolor emissions enabled by symmetry breaking
authors: Simin Lin
Xubin Wang
Huisi Li
Jiancheng Zhou
Ruijuan Wen
Jianfei Ma
Shiwei Yin
Ling-Ya Peng
Haonan Peng
Yu Fang
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63519-7 Excitation-dependent multicolour emission is desirable, but hard to obtain. Here, the authors report the development of a molecular symmetry breaking strategy to all excitation-dependent multicolour emissions from one chemical entity.

Yiqiu Zhang

Qiang Zhou
Xianzhang Bu
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63458-3 Researchers discover remodeling harmful Alzheimer disease-associated Amyloid-β species, rather than activating immune cells, enables their effective and safer removal in models, suggesting an alternative therapy design approach.

items.title: Metformin alters mitochondria-related metabolism and enhances human oligodendrocyte function
authors: Nina-Lydia Kazakou
Nadine Bestard-Cuche
Laura J. Wagstaff
Kellie Horan
Luise Seeker
Sunniva Bøstrand

Fabio Baldivia Pohl
Bjorn Neumann
Patrick Keeler
Robin J. M. Franklin
Anna Williams
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63279-4 Metformin is under clinical trial for brain neuroprotection but how it may work is poorly understood. Here, the authors show that metformin helps myelin formation by human oligodendrocytes and improves mitochondrial action in all brain cells.
